cards.term: archival research
cards.definition: method of research using past records or data sets to answer various research questions, or to search for interesting patterns or relationships

cards.term: method of research using past records or data sets to answer various research questions, or to search for interesting patterns or relationships
cards.definition: archival research

cards.term: attrition
cards.definition: reduction in number of research participants as some drop out of the study over time

cards.term: reduction in number of research participants as some drop out of the study over time
cards.definition: attrition

cards.term: cause-and-effect relationship
cards.definition: changes in one variable cause the changes in the other variable; can be determined only through an experimental research design

cards.term: changes in one variable cause the changes in the other variable; can be determined only through an experimental research design
cards.definition: cause-and-effect relationship

cards.term: clinical or case study
cards.definition: observational research study focusing on one or a few people

cards.term: observational research study focusing on one or a few people
cards.definition: clinical or case study

cards.term: confirmation bias
cards.definition: tendency to ignore evidence that disproves ideas or beliefs

cards.term: tendency to ignore evidence that disproves ideas or beliefs
cards.definition: confirmation bias

cards.term: confounding variable
cards.definition: unanticipated outside factor that affects both variables of interest, often giving the false impression that changes in one variable causes changes in the other variable, when, in actuality, the outside factor causes changes in both variables

cards.term: unanticipated outside factor that affects both variables of interest, often giving the false impression that changes in one variable causes changes in the other variable, when, in actuality, the outside factor causes changes in both variables
cards.definition: confounding variable

cards.term: control group
cards.definition: serves as a basis for comparison and controls for chance factors that might influence the results of the study—by holding such factors constant across groups so that the experimental manipulation is the only difference between groups

cards.term: serves as a basis for comparison and controls for chance factors that might influence the results of the study—by holding such factors constant across groups so that the experimental manipulation is the only difference between groups
cards.definition: control group

cards.term: correlation
cards.definition: relationship between two or more variables; when two variables are correlated, one variable changes as the other does

cards.term: relationship between two or more variables; when two variables are correlated, one variable changes as the other does
cards.definition: correlation

cards.term: correlation coefficient
cards.definition: number from -1 to +1, indicating the strength and direction of the relationship between variables, and usually represented by r

cards.term: number from -1 to +1, indicating the strength and direction of the relationship between variables, and usually represented by r
cards.definition: correlation coefficient

cards.term: cross-sectional research
cards.definition: compares multiple segments of a population at a single time

cards.term: compares multiple segments of a population at a single time
cards.definition: cross-sectional research

cards.term: debriefing
cards.definition: when an experiment involved deception, participants are told complete and truthful information about the experiment at its conclusion

cards.term: when an experiment involved deception, participants are told complete and truthful information about the experiment at its conclusion
cards.definition: debriefing

cards.term: deception
cards.definition: purposely misleading experiment participants in order to maintain the integrity of the experiment

cards.term: purposely misleading experiment participants in order to maintain the integrity of the experiment
cards.definition: deception

cards.term: deductive reasoning
cards.definition: results are predicted based on a general premise

cards.term: results are predicted based on a general premise
cards.definition: deductive reasoning

cards.term: dependent variable
cards.definition: variable that the researcher measures to see how much effect the independent variable had

cards.term: variable that the researcher measures to see how much effect the independent variable had
cards.definition: dependent variable

cards.term: double-blind study
cards.definition: experiment in which both the researchers and the participants are blind to group assignments

cards.term: experiment in which both the researchers and the participants are blind to group assignments
cards.definition: double-blind study

cards.term: empirical
cards.definition: grounded in objective, tangible evidence that can be observed time and time again, regardless of who is observing

cards.term: grounded in objective, tangible evidence that can be observed time and time again, regardless of who is observing
cards.definition: empirical

cards.term: experimental group
cards.definition: group designed to answer the research question; experimental manipulation is the only difference between the experimental and control groups, so any differences between the two are due to experimental manipulation rather than chance

cards.term: group designed to answer the research question; experimental manipulation is the only difference between the experimental and control groups, so any differences between the two are due to experimental manipulation rather than chance
cards.definition: experimental group

cards.term: experimenter bias
cards.definition: researcher expectations skew the results of the study

cards.term: researcher expectations skew the results of the study
cards.definition: experimenter bias

cards.term: fact
cards.definition: objective and verifiable observation, established using evidence collected through empirical research

cards.term: objective and verifiable observation, established using evidence collected through empirical research
cards.definition: fact

cards.term: falsifiable
cards.definition: able to be disproven by experimental results

cards.term: able to be disproven by experimental results
cards.definition: falsifiable

cards.term: generalize
cards.definition: inferring that the results for a sample apply to the larger population

cards.term: inferring that the results for a sample apply to the larger population
cards.definition: generalize

cards.term: hypothesis
cards.definition: tentative and testable statement about the relationship between two or more variables

cards.term: tentative and testable statement about the relationship between two or more variables
cards.definition: hypothesis

cards.term: illusory correlation
cards.definition: seeing relationships between two things when in reality no such relationship exists

cards.term: seeing relationships between two things when in reality no such relationship exists
cards.definition: illusory correlation

cards.term: independent variable
cards.definition: variable that is influenced or controlled by the experimenter; in a sound experimental study, the independent variable is the only important difference between the experimental and control group

cards.term: variable that is influenced or controlled by the experimenter; in a sound experimental study, the independent variable is the only important difference between the experimental and control group
cards.definition: independent variable

cards.term: independent variable
cards.definition: variable that is influenced or controlled by the experimenter; in a sound experimental study, the independent variable is the only important difference between the experimental and control group

cards.term: variable that is influenced or controlled by the experimenter; in a sound experimental study, the independent variable is the only important difference between the experimental and control group
cards.definition: independent variable

cards.term: inductive reasoning
cards.definition: conclusions are drawn from observations

cards.term: conclusions are drawn from observations
cards.definition: inductive reasoning

cards.term: informed consent
cards.definition: process of informing a research participant about what to expect during an experiment, any risks involved, and the implications of the research, and then obtaining the person's consent to participate

cards.term: process of informing a research participant about what to expect during an experiment, any risks involved, and the implications of the research, and then obtaining the person's consent to participate
cards.definition: informed consent

cards.term: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC)
cards.definition: committee of administrators, scientists, veterinarians, and community members that reviews proposals for research involving non-human animals

cards.term: committee of administrators, scientists, veterinarians, and community members that reviews proposals for research involving non-human animals
cards.definition: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC)

cards.term: Institutional Review Board (IRB)
cards.definition: committee of administrators, scientists, and community members that reviews proposals for research involving human participants

cards.term: committee of administrators, scientists, and community members that reviews proposals for research involving human participants
cards.definition: Institutional Review Board (IRB)

cards.term: inter-rater reliability
cards.definition: measure of agreement among observers on how they record and classify a particular event

cards.term: measure of agreement among observers on how they record and classify a particular event
cards.definition: inter-rater reliability

cards.term: longitudinal research
cards.definition: studies in which the same group of individuals is surveyed or measured repeatedly over an extended period of time

cards.term: studies in which the same group of individuals is surveyed or measured repeatedly over an extended period of time
cards.definition: longitudinal research

cards.term: naturalistic observation
cards.definition: observation of behavior in its natural setting

cards.term: observation of behavior in its natural setting
cards.definition: naturalistic observation

cards.term: negative correlation
cards.definition: two variables change in different directions, with one becoming larger as the other becomes smaller; a negative correlation is not the same thing as no correlation

cards.term: two variables change in different directions, with one becoming larger as the other becomes smaller; a negative correlation is not the same thing as no correlation
cards.definition: negative correlation

cards.term: observer bias
cards.definition: when observations may be skewed to align with observer expectations

cards.term: when observations may be skewed to align with observer expectations
cards.definition: observer bias

cards.term: operational definition
cards.definition: description of what actions and operations will be used to measure the dependent variables and manipulate the independent variables

cards.term: description of what actions and operations will be used to measure the dependent variables and manipulate the independent variables
cards.definition: operational definition

cards.term: opinion
cards.definition: personal judgments, conclusions, or attitudes that may or may not be accurate

cards.term: personal judgments, conclusions, or attitudes that may or may not be accurate
cards.definition: opinion

cards.term: participants
cards.definition: subjects of psychological research

cards.term: subjects of psychological research
cards.definition: participants

cards.term: peer-reviewed journal article
cards.definition: article read by several other scientists (usually anonymously) with expertise in the subject matter, who provide feedback regarding the quality of the manuscript before it is accepted for publication

cards.term: article read by several other scientists (usually anonymously) with expertise in the subject matter, who provide feedback regarding the quality of the manuscript before it is accepted for publication
cards.definition: peer-reviewed journal article

cards.term: placebo effect
cards.definition: people's expectations or beliefs influencing or determining their experience in a given situation

cards.term: people's expectations or beliefs influencing or determining their experience in a given situation
cards.definition: placebo effect

cards.term: population
cards.definition: overall group of individuals that the researchers are interested in

cards.term: overall group of individuals that the researchers are interested in
cards.definition: population

cards.term: positive correlation
cards.definition: two variables change in the same direction, both becoming either larger or smaller

cards.term: two variables change in the same direction, both becoming either larger or smaller
cards.definition: positive correlation

cards.term: random assignment
cards.definition: method of experimental group assignment in which all participants have an equal chance of being assigned to either group

cards.term: method of experimental group assignment in which all participants have an equal chance of being assigned to either group
cards.definition: random assignment

cards.term: random sample
cards.definition: subset of a larger population in which every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected

cards.term: subset of a larger population in which every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected
cards.definition: random sample

cards.term: reliability
cards.definition: consistency and reproducibility of a given result

cards.term: consistency and reproducibility of a given result
cards.definition: reliability

cards.term: replicate
cards.definition: repeating an experiment using different samples to determine the research's reliability

cards.term: repeating an experiment using different samples to determine the research's reliability
cards.definition: replicate

cards.term: sample
cards.definition: subset of individuals selected from the larger population

cards.term: subset of individuals selected from the larger population
cards.definition: sample

cards.term: single-blind study
cards.definition: experiment in which the researcher knows which participants are in the experimental group and which are in the control group

cards.term: experiment in which the researcher knows which participants are in the experimental group and which are in the control group
cards.definition: single-blind study

cards.term: statistical analysis
cards.definition: determines how likely any difference between experimental groups is due to chance

cards.term: determines how likely any difference between experimental groups is due to chance
cards.definition: statistical analysis

cards.term: survey
cards.definition: list of questions to be answered by research participants—given as paper-and-pencil questionnaires, administered electronically, or conducted verbally—allowing researchers to collect data from a large number of people

cards.term: list of questions to be answered by research participants—given as paper-and-pencil questionnaires, administered electronically, or conducted verbally—allowing researchers to collect data from a large number of people
cards.definition: survey

cards.term: theory
cards.definition: well-developed set of ideas that propose an explanation for observed phenomena

cards.term: well-developed set of ideas that propose an explanation for observed phenomena
cards.definition: theory

cards.term: validity
cards.definition: accuracy of a given result in measuring what it is designed to measure

cards.term: accuracy of a given result in measuring what it is designed to measure
cards.definition: validity

cards.term: Scientific hypotheses are ________ and falsifiable.
cards.definition: Testable

cards.term: Testable
cards.definition: Scientific hypotheses are ________ and falsifiable.

cards.term: ________ are defined as observable realities.
cards.definition: Facts

cards.term: Facts
cards.definition: ________ are defined as observable realities.

cards.term: Scientific knowledge is ________.
cards.definition: Empirical

cards.term: Empirical
cards.definition: Scientific knowledge is ________.

cards.term: A major criticism of Freud's early theories involves the fact that his theories ________.
cards.definition: Were not testable

cards.term: Were not testable
cards.definition: A major criticism of Freud's early theories involves the fact that his theories ________.

cards.term: Sigmund Freud developed his theory of human personality by conducting in-depth interviews over an extended period of time with a few clients. This type of research approach is known as a(n): ________.
cards.definition: Case study

cards.term: Case study
cards.definition: Sigmund Freud developed his theory of human personality by conducting in-depth interviews over an extended period of time with a few clients. This type of research approach is known as a(n): ________.

cards.term: ________ involves observing behavior in individuals in their natural environments.
cards.definition: Naturalistic observation

cards.term: Naturalistic observation
cards.definition: ________ involves observing behavior in individuals in their natural environments.

cards.term: The major limitation of case studies is ________.
cards.definition: The inability to generalize the findings from this approach to the larger population

cards.term: The inability to generalize the findings from this approach to the larger population
cards.definition: The major limitation of case studies is ________.

cards.term: The benefit of naturalistic observation studies is ________.
cards.definition: The honesty of the data that is collected in a realistic setting

cards.term: The honesty of the data that is collected in a realistic setting
cards.definition: The benefit of naturalistic observation studies is ________.

cards.term: Using existing records to try to answer a research question is known as ________.
cards.definition: Archival research

cards.term: Archival research
cards.definition: Using existing records to try to answer a research question is known as ________.

cards.term: ________ involves following a group of research participants for an extended period of time.
cards.definition: Longitudinal research

cards.term: Longitudinal research
cards.definition: ________ involves following a group of research participants for an extended period of time.

cards.term: A(n) ________ is a list of questions developed by a researcher that can be administered in paper form.
cards.definition: Survey

cards.term: Survey
cards.definition: A(n) ________ is a list of questions developed by a researcher that can be administered in paper form.

cards.term: Longitudinal research is complicated by high rates of ________.
cards.definition: Attrition

cards.term: Attrition
cards.definition: Longitudinal research is complicated by high rates of ________.

cards.term: Height and weight are positively correlated. This means that:
cards.definition: As height increases, typically weight increases

cards.term: As height increases, typically weight increases
cards.definition: Height and weight are positively correlated. This means that:

cards.term: Which of the following correlation coefficients indicates the strongest relationship between two variables?

cards.definition: Which of the following correlation coefficients indicates the strongest relationship between two variables?

cards.term: Which statement best illustrates a negative correlation between the number of hours spent watching TV the week before an exam and the grade on that exam?
cards.definition: Students who watch more television perform more poorly on their exams

cards.term: Students who watch more television perform more poorly on their exams
cards.definition: Which statement best illustrates a negative correlation between the number of hours spent watching TV the week before an exam and the grade on that exam?

cards.term: The correlation coefficient indicates the weakest relationship when ________.
cards.definition: It is closest to 0

cards.term: It is closest to 0
cards.definition: The correlation coefficient indicates the weakest relationship when ________.

cards.term: ________ means that everyone in the population has the same likelihood of being asked to participate in the study.
cards.definition: Random sampling

cards.term: Random sampling
cards.definition: ________ means that everyone in the population has the same likelihood of being asked to participate in the study.

cards.term: The ________ is controlled by the experimenter, while the ________ represents the information collected and statistically analyzed by the experimenter.
cards.definition: Independent variable; dependent variable

cards.term: Independent variable; dependent variable
cards.definition: The ________ is controlled by the experimenter, while the ________ represents the information collected and statistically analyzed by the experimenter.

cards.term: Researchers must ________ important concepts in their studies so others would have a clear understanding of exactly how those concepts were defined.
cards.definition: Operationalize

cards.term: Operationalize
cards.definition: Researchers must ________ important concepts in their studies so others would have a clear understanding of exactly how those concepts were defined.

cards.term: Sometimes, researchers will administer a(n) ________ to participants in the control group to control for the effects that participant expectation might have on the experiment.
cards.definition: Placebo

cards.term: Placebo
cards.definition: Sometimes, researchers will administer a(n) ________ to participants in the control group to control for the effects that participant expectation might have on the experiment.

cards.term: ________ is to animal research as ________ is to human research.
cards.definition: IACUC; IRB

cards.term: IACUC; IRB
cards.definition: ________ is to animal research as ________ is to human research.

cards.term: Researchers might use ________ when providing participants with the full details of the experiment could skew their responses.
cards.definition: Deception

cards.term: Deception
cards.definition: Researchers might use ________ when providing participants with the full details of the experiment could skew their responses.

cards.term: A person's participation in a research project must be ________.
cards.definition: Voluntary

cards.term: Voluntary
cards.definition: A person's participation in a research project must be ________.

cards.term: Before participating in an experiment, individuals should read and sign the ________ form.
cards.definition: Informed consent

cards.term: Informed consent
cards.definition: Before participating in an experiment, individuals should read and sign the ________ form.

cards.term: Fact vs. Opinion
cards.definition: Facts are observable realities. Opinions are personal judgments, conclusions, or attitudes that may or may not be accurate.

cards.term: Facts are observable realities. Opinions are personal judgments, conclusions, or attitudes that may or may not be accurate.
cards.definition: Fact vs. Opinion

cards.term: Margaret Floy Washburn
cards.definition: The first woman to earn a PhD in psychology (1871-1939).

cards.term: The first woman to earn a PhD in psychology (1871-1939).
cards.definition: Margaret Floy Washburn

cards.term: Francis Sumner
cards.definition: The first African American to receive a PhD in psychology (1920).

cards.term: The first African American to receive a PhD in psychology (1920).
cards.definition: Francis Sumner

cards.term: Falsifiability
cards.definition: The ability for a hypothesis to be shown to be incorrect; a key requirement for scientific hypotheses.

cards.term: The ability for a hypothesis to be shown to be incorrect; a key requirement for scientific hypotheses.
cards.definition: Falsifiability

cards.term: Experimental vs Control Group
cards.definition: The Experimental group gets the manipulation/treatment. The Control group does not.

cards.term: The Experimental group gets the manipulation/treatment. The Control group does not.
cards.definition: Experimental vs Control Group

cards.term: Peer-Reviewed
cards.definition: Articles read by several other scientists (peers) with expertise in the subject matter, who judge if the work is suitable for publication.

cards.term: Articles read by several other scientists (peers) with expertise in the subject matter, who judge if the work is suitable for publication.
cards.definition: Peer-Reviewed
